articles.headline: Two Black Students Won School Honors. Then Came the Calls for a Recount.
articles.snippet: After two white families claimed a grade calculation error, a Mississippi school added their children as co-valedictorian and co-salutatorian, reviving questions about race and equity.
articles.abstract: After two white families claimed a grade calculation error, a Mississippi school added their children as co-valedictorian and co-salutatorian, reviving questions about race and equity.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first, it seemed a joyous occasion. There was an audible gasp in the room, then boisterous cheering and applause when the announcement was made: Ikeria Washington and Layla Temple had been named 2021 valedictorian and salutatorian for West Point High School.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Lawmakers, Taking Aim at Big Tech, Push Sweeping Overhaul of Antitrust
articles.snippet: A bipartisan group of House members introduced five bills targeting Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
articles.abstract: A bipartisan group of House members introduced five bills targeting Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers on Friday introduced sweeping antitrust legislation aimed at restraining the power of Big Tech and staving off corporate consolidation. If passed, the bills would be the most ambitious update to monopoly laws in decades.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Companies Desperate to Reopen Ask: What’s Your Vaccination Status?
articles.snippet: Companies are sending surveys, offering cash rewards and requiring disclosures to find out how much of their work force is vaccinated.
articles.abstract: Companies are sending surveys, offering cash rewards and requiring disclosures to find out how much of their work force is vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The message from many companies to their office workers is clear. It will soon be time to shed the slippers for hard shoes and return to your desk. But many companies are still puzzling over a single quandary: What to do about vaccines. Should they require employees to get them? Encourage or cajole or bribe them?
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: What Drives Joe Manchin? Frustrated Democrats Can Look to West Virginia.
articles.snippet: The senator has become a lightning rod in his party and a major obstacle to President Biden’s agenda. In his home state, his stubborn belief in bipartisanship is recognized as the core of his being.
articles.abstract: The senator has become a lightning rod in his party and a major obstacle to President Biden’s agenda. In his home state, his stubborn belief in bipartisanship is recognized as the core of his being.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, W.Va. — Decades ago, John Manchin Jr., a civic leader in a small coal town in West Virginia, lent his support to a Democrat running for Congress. His candidate lost to a Republican named Arch Moore Jr.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: In Leak Investigation, Tech Giants Are Caught Between Courts and Customers
articles.snippet: Apple, under fire for turning over the data of two lawmakers to the Trump Justice Dept., said it did so unknowingly, while Google fought a request for New York Times data because it related to a corporate client.
articles.abstract: Apple, under fire for turning over the data of two lawmakers to the Trump Justice Dept., said it did so unknowingly, while Google fought a request for New York Times data because it related to a corporate client.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 6, 2018, Apple received a grand jury subpoena for the names and phone records connected to 109 email addresses and phone numbers. It was one of the more than 250 data requests that the company received on average from U.S. law enforcement each week at the time. An Apple paralegal complied and provided the information.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Daisuke Wakabayashi and Katie Benner

articles.headline: F.D.A. Tells Johnson & Johnson That 60 Million Vaccine Doses Cannot Be Used
articles.snippet: The agency has not decided whether to allow a troubled vaccine factory in Baltimore to reopen.
articles.abstract: The agency has not decided whether to allow a troubled vaccine factory in Baltimore to reopen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators said on Friday that millions of doses of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine produced at a troubled Baltimore factory could not be used, the latest in a series of setbacks for a company whose single-shot vaccine was once considered crucial to the nation’s inoculation campaign.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Watchdog to Investigate Seizure of Democrats’ Data
articles.snippet: Democrats denounced the Trump administration’s seizure of lawmakers’ data as an abuse of power and called on Republicans to back the congressional inquiry.
articles.abstract: Democrats denounced the Trump administration’s seizure of lawmakers’ data as an abuse of power and called on Republicans to back the congressional inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s independent inspector general opened an investigation on Friday into the decision by federal prosecutors to secretly seize the data of House Democrats and reporters as investigators hunted down who was leaking classified information early in the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Garland Pledges Renewed Efforts to Protect Voting Rights
articles.snippet: The attorney general’s commitment served notice to Republican-led states imposing new voting restrictions, and included a vow to protect the voting rights of people of color.
articles.abstract: The attorney general’s commitment served notice to Republican-led states imposing new voting restrictions, and included a vow to protect the voting rights of people of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland laid out an expansive plan on Friday for protecting voting rights, announcing that the Justice Department would double enforcement staff on the issue, scrutinize new state laws that seek to curb voter access and take action if it sees a violation of federal law.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: ‘Take the Ship’: Conservatives Aim to Commandeer Southern Baptists
articles.snippet: The insurgents, some adopting a pirate motif, believe that the denomination has drifted too far to the left on issues of race, gender and the strict authority of the Bible.
articles.abstract: The insurgents, some adopting a pirate motif, believe that the denomination has drifted too far to the left on issues of race, gender and the strict authority of the Bible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allen Nelson IV walked to the front of his small church in central Arkansas, stopped in front of the communion table with three large crosses behind him, and unfurled a giant black flag with a white skull and crossed swords.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: Private Inequity: How a Powerful Industry Conquered the Tax System
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. almost never audits private equity firms, even as whistle-blowers have filed claims alleging illegal tax avoidance.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. almost never audits private equity firms, even as whistle-blowers have filed claims alleging illegal tax avoidance.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were two weeks left in the Trump administration when the Treasury Department handed down a set of rules governing an obscure corner of the tax code.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: What Is a Flying Car?
articles.snippet: Inside Silicon Valley’s 10-year quest to make soaring above a crowded city street as easy as calling an Uber.
articles.abstract: Inside Silicon Valley’s 10-year quest to make soaring above a crowded city street as easy as calling an Uber.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Biden Tries to Rally G7 Nations to Counter China’s Influence
articles.snippet: The president urged the leaders of wealthy democracies to offer hundreds of billions in loans to developing nations in a direct challenge to Beijing’s Belt-and-Road Initiative.
articles.abstract: The president urged the leaders of wealthy democracies to offer hundreds of billions in loans to developing nations in a direct challenge to Beijing’s Belt-and-Road Initiative.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, England — President Biden urged European nations and Japan on Saturday to counter China’s growing economic and security influence by offering developing nations hundreds of billions in financing as an alternative to relying on Beijing for new roads, railways, ports and communications networks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Why the Mexico City Metro Collapsed
articles.snippet: A Times investigation shows the serious construction flaws and political pressure behind a tragedy that threatens two of Mexico’s most prominent figures.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation shows the serious construction flaws and political pressure behind a tragedy that threatens two of Mexico’s most prominent figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Times investigation shows the serious construction flaws and political pressure behind a tragedy that threatens two of Mexico’s most prominent figures.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, Maria Abi-Habib, James Glanz, Oscar Lopez, Weiyi Cai, Evan Grothjan, Miles Peyton and Alejandro Cegarra

articles.headline: Apple Is Said to Have Turned Over Data on Trump’s White House Counsel in 2018
articles.snippet: The company notified Donald F. McGahn II last month that it had been subpoenaed for his account information three years ago.
articles.abstract: The company notified Donald F. McGahn II last month that it had been subpoenaed for his account information three years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department subpoenaed Apple for information in February 2018 about an account that belonged to Donald F. McGahn II, President Donald J. Trump’s White House counsel at the time, and barred the company from telling him about it, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Netanyahu, ‘King of Israel,’ Exits a Stage He Dominated
articles.snippet: Israel’s longest-serving prime minister was a polarizing figure who sidelined efforts to resolve the Palestinian conflict but opened relations with four Arab countries.
articles.abstract: Israel’s longest-serving prime minister was a polarizing figure who sidelined efforts to resolve the Palestinian conflict but opened relations with four Arab countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He came to power like some conqueror from a distant land called Philadelphia.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: G7 Leaders Offer United Front as Summit Ends, but Cracks Are Clear
articles.snippet: Biden and other Western leaders had tough words for Russia and China after wrapping up a meeting in England, but they had trouble finding common ground on some big issues.
articles.abstract: Biden and other Western leaders had tough words for Russia and China after wrapping up a meeting in England, but they had trouble finding common ground on some big issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Biden and fellow Western leaders issued a confrontational declaration about Russian and Chinese government behavior on Sunday, castigating Beijing over its internal repression, vowing to investigate the pandemic’s origins, and excoriating Moscow for using nerve agents and cyberweapons.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Netanyahu Ousted as Israeli Parliament Votes in New Government
articles.snippet: An unlikely coalition prevailed against the country’s longest-serving leader. Now it must get its disparate factions to work together.
articles.abstract: An unlikely coalition prevailed against the country’s longest-serving leader. Now it must get its disparate factions to work together.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The long and divisive reign of Benjamin Netanyahu, the dominant Israeli politician of the past generation, officially ended on Sunday night, at least for the time being, as the country’s Parliament gave its vote of confidence to a precarious coalition government stitched together by widely disparate anti-Netanyahu forces.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Why The New Yorker’s Stars Didn’t Join Its Union
articles.snippet: The 96-year-old magazine, known for its revered writers and sophisticated audience, is being consumed by a labor dispute.
articles.abstract: The 96-year-old magazine, known for its revered writers and sophisticated audience, is being consumed by a labor dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: Writers for The New Yorker have been known to refer to the editor, David Remnick, as “Dad,” so there was something a little illicit about their decision to gather without him back in 2018 at a Windsor Terrace apartment.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: To Fill Millions of Open Jobs, Many Workers Need More Than Skills
articles.snippet: Helping people land good jobs with career paths takes more than skills training, labor experts say. Coaching, mentoring and other assistance are also needed.
articles.abstract: Helping people land good jobs with career paths takes more than skills training, labor experts say. Coaching, mentoring and other assistance are also needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rachelle Katchenago of Menasha, Wis., lost her job as a call-center contract worker last year after the pandemic lockdowns took hold. No one was hiring.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Black Virginians Took Ralph Northam Back. Neither Has Forgotten.
articles.snippet: Virginia’s governor survived a blackface scandal with the help of Black Democrats, who saw a chance for policy concessions. Both got more from the relationship than they could have imagined.
articles.abstract: Virginia’s governor survived a blackface scandal with the help of Black Democrats, who saw a chance for policy concessions. Both got more from the relationship than they could have imagined.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Alonzo Jones, a Black mayor in Southern Virginia, was used to the playbook of a white politician facing allegations of racism.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Lordstown, Truck Maker That Can’t Afford to Make Trucks, Is on the Brink
articles.snippet: The company’s top executive resigned after the struggling automaker released an investigation by its board.
articles.abstract: The company’s top executive resigned after the struggling automaker released an investigation by its board.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, was attacked by President Donald J. Trump for closing an Ohio factory, the solution was a start-up called Lordstown Motors.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Lauren Hirsch and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: A Top Virologist in China, at Center of a Pandemic Storm, Speaks Out
articles.snippet: The virologist, Shi Zhengli, said in a rare interview that speculation about her lab in Wuhan was baseless. But China’s habitual secrecy makes her claims hard to validate.
articles.abstract: The virologist, Shi Zhengli, said in a rare interview that speculation about her lab in Wuhan was baseless. But China’s habitual secrecy makes her claims hard to validate.
articles.lead_paragraph: To a growing chorus of American politicians and scientists, she is the key to whether the world will ever learn if the virus behind the devastating Covid-19 pandemic escaped from a Chinese lab. To the Chinese government and public, she is a hero of the country’s success in curbing the epidemic and a victim of malicious conspiracy theories.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Why the World Needs More Black Accountants
articles.snippet: The field of accounting is overwhelmingly white. Rumbi Bwerinofa-Petrozzello, a forensic accountant, wants to change that.
articles.abstract: The field of accounting is overwhelmingly white. Rumbi Bwerinofa-Petrozzello, a forensic accountant, wants to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: The field of accounting is overwhelmingly white, a racial group that makes up 84 percent of all certified public accountants in the United States. Of the nonwhite groups, just 2 percent are Black, according to a report published in 2019 by the Association of International Certified Public Accountants.
articles.byline: By Wadzanai Mhute
